item.title: Hank Effect to screen at Intensive Arts
item.dc:creator: Tory
item.description: I am working with the School of Filmmaking staff to arrange a standalone screening of The Hank Effect during this year’s spring Intensive Arts. Stay tuned for details!
item.content:encoded: I am working with the School of Filmmaking staff to arrange a standalone screening of The Hank Effect during this year’s spring Intensive Arts. Stay tuned for details!

item.title: Mari Muerta approaches picture lock
item.dc:creator: Tory
item.description: In the hands of editor Marc Sutton, Mari Muerta rapidly approaches picture completion. Next it goes to sound editor Joe Morgan, who will put the spooky swerve on the action. The hope is to have the film completed before commencement on May 31. A thousand thanks to everyone involved for your hard work. We are closing [...]
item.content:encoded:
In the hands of editor Marc Sutton, Mari Muerta rapidly approaches picture completion. Next it goes to sound editor Joe Morgan, who will put the spooky swerve on the action. The hope is to have the film completed before commencement on May 31.

A thousand thanks to everyone involved for your hard work. We are closing in.

item.title: Hank Effect to screen at Women’s International Film Festival
item.dc:creator: Tory
item.description: The Hank Effect at WIFF - Part of the Student Program which screens 7:00 PM Monday, March 31. The Women’s International Film Festival takes place in Miami, FL from March 28 - April 6. Of course, all cast and crew are welcome to go! I’ve requested information on tickets. If you order now for the last week of [...]
item.content:encoded:
The Hank Effect at WIFF - Part of the Student Program which screens 7:00 PM Monday, March 31.

The Women’s International Film Festival takes place in Miami, FL from March 28 - April 6.

Of course, all cast and crew are welcome to go! I’ve requested information on tickets.

If you order now for the last week of March, SkyBus is available from Greensboro to Fort Lauderdale for about $120 round-trip.

Feel free to contact me with any questions. THANK YOU! WE DID IT!

item.title: Mari Muerta - Brochure
item.dc:creator: Tory
item.description:
T-Party Films is seeking donations for Mari Muerta — a 10-minute family dramedy, and the follow-up to The Hank Effect.
Production is complete on Mari Muerta, and updates will be posted as we go. But we still have a long way to go, from editing to festival fees, and every bit counts. So what is this one [...]
item.content:encoded:
T-Party Films is seeking donations for Mari Muerta — a 10-minute family dramedy, and the follow-up to The Hank Effect.

Production is complete on Mari Muerta, and updates will be posted as we go. But we still have a long way to go, from editing to festival fees, and every bit counts.

So what is this one about?

A confirmed bachelor is driven to the breaking point by the little girl haunting his house.

  • Download the script - English (PDF)
  • Download the script - Spanish (PDF)
  • View production photos

Synopsis (spoilers, of course):

Comic book artist Bert comes home from a lackluster job interview to find his house turned upside-down by a poltergeist… again. When Mariquita manifests, J-Horror style, Bert barely looks up from his spaghetti dinner. Still, as the two recap their day, he agrees to play a game with her – until his phone rings.

The job interview was a success. They want to see the first page by the morning.

Bert has to decide – work or Battleship? Work wins, hands down. Hurt, Mari tries everything she can to prevent him from finishing – overturning his spaghetti, throwing furniture, putting out the light – to no avail. She leaves him alone – and happy to be so.

Deep in the night, he finally finishes and goes to bed. His phone drags him back to the office, though, as the recruiter wants to know how it went.

He finds his precious page destroyed – by Mari.

Furious, Bert rants and fumes in the empty room. He doesn’t see Mari appear until he’s already said something terrible – and something she’s been told before.

What happens next is far beyond Mari’s regular disturbances.

Once things settle down (and he finds a flashlight), Bert begs Mari to let him talk to her. She eventually permits him to join her in her sacred space — the linen closet. There, Bert learns the real source of Mari’s emotions – she left behind a little sister. Mari’s afraid her sister’s childhood is turning out no better than her own.

Bert realizes how Mari can contact her father. Together, they write him a letter.

No sooner has Mari sealed the envelope than she begins to cross over! Goodbye, Mari. The house is empty.

Now alone, Bert honors Mari’s memory – with her own comic book, and with one more overturned bowl of spaghetti.

And what’s the point?

That there are fates worse than death. Like being forgotten.

item.title: The Hank Effect - Floyd’s Lecture
item.dc:creator: Tory
item.description: The scene where Floyd explains to Hank and Cheryl what the heck is going on. PG-13 for a line of dialogue that just couldn’t be changed.
item.content:encoded:
The scene where Floyd explains to Hank and Cheryl what the heck is going on.

item.title: The Hank Effect - DVDs
item.dc:creator: Tory
item.description: DVDs are burned and on their way to cast, crew, locations and donors — they will be in school mailboxes by tomorrow at noon, and in real live postal mailboxes by Christmas. Thank you to everyone who made this possible. I hope you enjoy the results. Coming next: Mari Muerta
item.content:encoded:
DVDs are burned and on their way to cast, crew, locations and donors — they will be in school mailboxes by tomorrow at noon, and in real live postal mailboxes by Christmas. Thank you to everyone who made this possible. I hope you enjoy the results.

Coming next: Mari Muerta

item.title: Hank Effect - Behind the Scenes Videos
item.dc:creator: Tory
item.content:encoded:
If there’s anything I’ve learned from watching these, is that I’m loud and self-obsessed. Also that I should not be operating a camera. But I think I knew all of these.

Talking to Drew and Ryan, about Drew’s knee and Ryan’s kissin’

Harrassing Carrie, the makeup artist, and Rachel, the cinematographer. This one makes me pee my pants.

Harrassing Jenn, the art director, and Cait, her assistant, who is also helping with wardrobe, which is not art department.

Back to harrassing Rachel. Says I, “We got out of our first two locations an hour early.” Says she, “Well… I do that.”
